anatomy.anatomyJwt: What does a JWT look like? (Anatomy of a JWT)
anatomy.anatomyJwt1: This is a practical example of a JWT.
anatomy.anatomyJwt3: Sure it does look like garbage, but it is not. In the next few minutes, you'll see how easy it is to turn this garbage into useful information.
anatomy.header1: This part is the metadata about the cryptography methods used for signature. e.g. The Cryptography Algorithm, Token type, etc.
anatomy.header2: What! Where? It is not readable.
anatomy.header3: Hold on. The header is encoded with base64UrlEncode, and can easily be decoded by anyone without any additional information other than the token itself. Let's decode this header with browser's atob() method.
anatomy.payload1: Actual data we want to exchange via this token e.g. userId.
anatomy.payload2: This is also encoded with base64UrlEncode. Just like the header, let's decode payload as well with browser's atob() method.
anatomy.showDecodedHeader: (This will show you the decoded header in plain text)
anatomy.showDecodedPayload: (This will show you the decoded payload in plain text)
anatomy.signature1: To verify sender or ensure token data integrity.
anatomy.signature2: What if this token was tampered somewhere in between when it traveled from the server(where it was created) to your browser(where you're seeing it right now)? You can verify that. >To verify the token integrity, you'll need to know something more than just the token. You'll need to know a public key corresponding to the private-key used during the creation of this token.
anatomy.signature2Tooltip: In public-key cryptography, a pair of keys is used. A private key is used to create a signature for a message which then can be verified by anyone who has the public key.
anatomy.signature3: Luckily, I am the token creator here (for the example token I just showed you). I used a pair of public/private keys for this token and I'm sharing the public key with you, now you go ahead and verify JWT integrity with this public key.
anatomy.signature4: The public key (from the public-private key pair I used to secure the token).
anatomy.takeawayHeader: Takeaway: The header can be decoded by anyone. It's not garbage for anyone.
anatomy.takeawayPayload: Takeaway: The payload can be decoded by anyone. It's not garbage for anyone.
anatomy.tokenNew: Generated a new token signed with secret!
anatomy.tokenSchema1: Did you notice two dots(.) in the token? These dots (.) separate 3 important parts of the token.
anatomy.verifyJwt: Use this Public Key to Verify JWT

home.introduction1: This is an interactive tutorial to learn about JWT by reverse engineering.
home.introduction2: By the end of this tutorial, you'll learn what a JWT is and how you can implement authentication using JWTs in your app.
home.introduction3: We'll start with examples and then reverse engineer by deconstructing each part.

home.learnJwt: Learn JWT by reverse engineering & debug easily

verify.verified1: It was verified successfully, what does it mean? It means that the token was exactly the same as when it was created. This verification would have failed, if say a sneaky hacker had intercepted our communication and modified the token before it reached your machine. This is very useful. Isn't it?
verify.verified2: Takeaway: Unlike header and payload, the signature is garbage for everyone, except for someone who got access to the public key from the token creator.
verify.verified3: Ok, it seems cool but how is this structure useful? How can I use a JWT?

jwtusedfor.introduction1: JWTs can be used as a digital claim issued by one party, which another party can verify for integrity.
jwtusedfor.typicalUse1: To prove whether a user is logged in or not
jwtusedfor.typicalUse2: To prove whether a user is authorized to perform admin actions or not
jwtusedfor.introduction2: What’s more interesting? In order to verify JWT integrity, the other party(one that verifies) does not need to communicate with the first party(one that created JWT). Well, assuming the first party has shared the public key with the other party already.
jwtusedfor.leverage: So what if I leverage this to create a system as following
jwtusedfor.leverage1: A computer verifies user identity(e.g. username/password) and issues JWTs to the users. Let’s call it an “identity server”
jwtusedfor.leverage2: Another computer that takes requests for users’ protected resources, let’s call it “application server”. It asks for JWT along with the request. This computer(application server) verifies the JWT and makes sure that the JWT was not tampered with
jwtusedfor.leverage3: And then the above “application server” uses JWT payload data to decide whether to give access to a particular resource or not. Essentially allowing the access to users as “identity server” wanted (remember the identity server created the JWT in step 1, at that time, it had also put in the access related necessary info in the JWT)
jwtusedfor.leverage4: What if we can show a drawing showcasing the JWT issue counter vs JWT verification+access counter. Similar to how token system work at Dominos work.
jwtusedfor.introduction3: This is a typical example of authentication/authorization using JWTs and the interesting thing here is that you separated the work related to identity vs work related to actual user resources. You don’t need to rely on a single central system any more to effectively do this and thus can scale and manage in a better way.

best-method.introduction: Choosing the best method to send tokens to auth server
best-method.method: So, which method is the best method to send token to authorization server?
best-method.method1: For APIs, the recommended approach is to send token in authorization header as per Oauth RFC (Bearer Token)
best-method.method2: For web, it's debatable how to send and store the token, considering the possible attacks(e.g. XSS, CSRF, etc) vs Performance
best-method.method3: So now, we can generate token, we can send it to server to access the protected resource, verify if the token is valid.
best-method.implement: But how do we implement logout?

logout.warningMessage: This is a complex and highly debatable topic. Don't leave without reading the last paragraph.
logout.noAccess: You may simply remove the token from the client side => No token, No access
logout.valid: The token you created earlier is still valid(till the expiry time of that token). So if anyone who makes the request with that token, will get access to the protected resources just like before.
logout.valid1: Also what happens when you change your password? The token is still valid.
logout.introduction1: So, what are common strategies to avoid such misuse of the tokens?
logout.strategy1: Create a token blacklist e.g. on logout request, add the token to blacklist; use the blacklist to deny access to tokens which are still valid but should not be authorized
logout.strategy2: Keep token expiry times short and rotate them often
logout.strategy3: Contingency Plan : allow the user to change an underlying user lookup ID with their login credentials
logout.strategy4: A common approach for invalidating tokens when a user changes their password is to sign the token with a hash of their password. Thus if the password changes, any previous tokens automatically fail to verify. You can extend this to logout by including a last-logout-time in the user's record and using a combination of the last-logout-time and password hash to sign the token. This requires a DB lookup each time you need to verify the token signature, but presumably you're looking up the user anyway.
logout.strategy5: These strategies can be debated based on the trade offs that need to be made between Performance vs Security.

disclosures.disclosure1: In this tutorial, we focused only on JWS - a particular type of JWT that is secured with digital signatures. It is the most commonly used type of JWT when people talk in the context of authentication. The other type is JWE which means the token is encrypted so unlike JWS, JWE header/payload is not readable by anyone else who doesn’t have the keys to decrypt.
disclosures.disclosure2: We always talked about the need of public/private keys to verify/sign the token which means we were assuming to use public-private keys cryptography for the signature. While most practical applications, you’ll be using public-keys cryptography only, this is not the only standard to do it, you could also use MAC
